{{Infobox mountain | name = Mount KrÃ¼ger | photo = | photo_caption = | elevation_m = 2655 | elevation_ref = | prominence = | listing = | location = [[Queen Maud Land]], [[Antarctica]] | range = [[Sverdrup Mountains]] | coordinates = {{coord|72|36|S|0|57|E |type:mountain_region:AQ_dim:200000 |display=inline,title}} | topo = | type = | age = | first_ascent = | easiest_route = }} '''Mount KrÃ¼ger''', or '''KrÃ¼gerfjellet''', is a {{convert|2655|m|adj=on}} [[mountain]] standing {{convert|8|mi}} southwest of [[Kvitho Peak]] in the [[Sverdrup Mountains]] of [[Queen Maud Land]], [[Antarctica]].<ref name="gnis"/> The summit of KrÃ¼ger is the highest point in the Sverdrup Mtns.<ref>{{cite web | url= http://www.peakbagger.com/peak.aspx?pid=12323 | title= Mount KrÃ¼ger, Antarctica |author= |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date= |year= |month= | publisher= Peakbagger.com | accessdate= 2009-08-09 }}</ref>
== Discovery and naming == Mount KrÃ¼ger was discovered by the [[Third German Antarctic Expedition]] (1938â1939), led by Capt. [[Alfred Ritscher]], and named for Walter KrÃ¼ger, meteorological assistant on the expedition. It was surveyed by the [[Norwegian-British-Swedish Antarctic Expedition]] (NBSAE) (1949â1952), led by [[John Schjelderup GiÃ¦ver]].<ref name="gnis">{{cite gnis | type = antarid | id = 8255 | name = Mount KrÃ¼ger | accessdate = 2009-08-09 }}</ref> {{-}} == See also == * [[East Antarctica Ranges]] * [[East Antarctic two-thousanders]] * [[History of Antarctica]] * [[List of Antarctic expeditions]]
